APPLICATION APCATA 14245 S0926-860X(13)00315-3 10.1016/j.apcata.2013.05.033 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Absorption spectra of (a) Au, (b) Mn3O4, (c) Au–Mn3O4 (MO) and (d) Au–Mn3O4 (OO) nanoparticles. Inset shows a closer view in the range of 400–700nm represented by a′, b′, c′ and d′ respectively. Condition: [Mn(ac)2]=0.5mM, [Au]=0.05mM, [PVP]=20mM (R =40), H2O:EtOH=1:0, 1:0, 3:1, 1:1 for Au, Mn3O4, Au–Mn3O4 (MO), Au–Mn3O4 (OO), respectively. Fig. 2 TEM images and the corresponding diameter histogram of (a) Mn3O4, (b) Au, (c) many-to-one (MO) and (d) one-to-one (OO) Au–Mn3O4 nanoparticles. Fig. 3 Representative EDX pattern of (a) Mn3O4 and (b) Au–Mn3O4 (MO) nanoparticles. Fig. 4 (a and b) HRTEM, (c and d) STEM images and (e and f) SAED patterns of Mn3O4 (Au in the inset) of many-to-one (MO; a, c, and e) and one-to-one (OO; b, d, and f) Au–Mn3O4 nanoparticles, respectively. Fig. 5 X-ray diffraction patterns of the nanoparticles of (a) Au, (b) Mn3O4, (c) Au–Mn3O4 (MO) and (d) after annealing of the Au–Mn3O4 (MO) nanocomposites at 500°C in argon atmosphere for 1h. Fig. 6 Hysteresis loops of Mn3O4 and Au–Mn3O4 (MO) nanoparticles at 1.85K. Inset shows no significant change in the hysteresis curve upon addition of Au at room temperature (300K). Fig. 7 RRDE voltammograms for the ORR, in O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4, at GC electrode deposited with nanoparticles of (a) Mn3O4, (b) Au, (c) Au–Mn3O4 (OO) and (d) Au–Mn3O4 (MO). An aliquot of 30μL of 0.5mM of each colloidal solution was deposited for comparison. Rotation rate: 900rpm. Potential scan rate of the disk electrode: 200mVs−1. Solvent-mediated synthesis, characterization and electrocatalytic activity of hydrophilic and dispersive Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites Sujit Kumar Ghosh a Junjie Kang a Makoto Inokuchi a Naoki Toshima a b ⁎ a Department of Applied Chemistry, Tokyo University of Science, Yamaguchi, Sanyo-Onoda, Yamaguchi 756-0884, Japan Department of Applied Chemistry, Tokyo University of Science, Yamaguchi Sanyo-Onoda Yamaguchi 756-0884 Japan b CREST, Japan Science and Technology Agency, Kawaguchi, Saitama 332-0012, Japan CREST, Japan Science and Technology Agency Kawaguchi Saitama 332-0012 Japan ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Gold/manganese oxide nanocomposites have been synthesized by seed-mediated epitaxial growth of manganese oxide on the surface of gold nanoparticles under hydrothermal condition. The architectures of the nanocomposites were varied by tuning the composition of the solvent employed in the reaction medium. The particles have been characterized by UV–vis spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) techniques. Magnetic measurements show that there are no significant changes in the magnetic moment and coercivity of Mn3O4 nanoparticles upon conjugation with the gold nanoparticles. These bifunctional nanoconjugates have been found to serve as efficient electrocatalysts in comparison with their individual counterparts for the oxygen reduction reaction. The differences in the structure–function relationship of the Au–Mn3O4 composites arise from distinct surface properties of the catalysts. Keywords Nanocomposites Manganese oxides Epitaxial growth Hydrothermal reaction Magnetic coercivity Electrocatalytic activity 1 Introduction In recent years, the fabrication of nanocomposites containing two or more different functionalities is of immense interest for the development of advanced nanomaterials from both scientific and technological viewpoints [1]. With controlled structure and interface interactions, these nanocomposites exhibit novel physical and chemical properties that are essential for potential technological applications in areas, such as, ferrofluids, medical imaging, drug targeting and delivery, cancer therapy, separations, and catalysis [2]. The bifunctional composite nanostructures containing gold have found tremendous importance in the field of nanocatalysis due to rich surface chemistry of gold [3]. On the other hand, manganese oxides are materials of considerable importance due to their interesting magnetic, structural and transport properties that arises from their outstanding structural flexibility combined with novel chemical and physical properties [4–7]. Among the series of manganese oxides available in various oxidation states of manganese (II, III, IV), Mn3O4 (hausmannite) has been found to be an effective and inexpensive catalyst in a number of oxidation and reduction reactions, e.g., for the oxidation of methane [8], the selective reduction of nitrobenzene [9], or the limitation of the emission of NO x and CO which provides a powerful method in alleviating several air pollution problems [10]. For gold-coupled binary catalysts, it is now well-established that the catalytic activity of gold depends not only on the size of the particles, but also on the nature of the support material, the preparation method, and the activation procedure [11–13]. It has been proposed that the reducible metal oxide support supplies oxygen to form active gold sites [14]. Sites at the gold–support interface (so-called “perimeter effect” proposed by M. Haruta) have also been claimed to be responsible for the activity in CO oxidation [3,15]. Other explanations focus on the charge transfer between the support, particularly negatively charged defects (F centers), and the gold particles [16]. In addition, the effects of low co-ordinated sites and surface roughness have also been suggested [17]. Gold/manganese oxide catalysts prepared by co-precipitation method have been reported to be active catalysts for low-temperature CO oxidation reactions [18]. Gardner's group reported that Au/MnO x catalysts show better catalytic performance for this reaction than Pt/SnO2 [19]. They also observed a dependence of catalytic activity of Au/MnO x on alkali metal ions, including, Li+, Na+ and K+ and proposed that the existence of alkali metal ions on the Au/MnO x catalysts may suppress retention of CO2 on the catalyst surface [20]. Torres Sanchez et al. observed 100% CO conversion on Au/MnO x catalysts in H2 stream, which could be applicable for polymer electrolyte fuel cells (PEFCs) [21]. The various Au catalysts supported on MnO2 exhibit high activities at low temperatures and a long lifetime in catalysis for CO oxidation [22]. Sinha et al. have demonstrated a surfactant-assisted wet chemical route to obtain high surface area mesoporous γ-MnO2/nanogold catalysts and catalytic activity of these materials for the efficient elimination of volatile organic compounds [13]. El-Deab and Ohsaka have investigated the effect of loading level of binary catalysts comprised of nano-Au and nano-MnO x electrodeposited on glassy carbon electrode on the electrochemical reduction of molecular oxygen in alkaline solution [23]. Li and co-authors have reported gold nanoparticle-mediated hybrid nanoassembly of Au/MnO2 for H2O2 amperometric sensing [24]. Lang and co-workers have developed electrochemical supercapacitors made of nanoporous gold and nanocrystalline MnO2 where the electron transport is facilitated by metal through the metal oxide nanostructures [25]. Martínez et al. have described the fabrication of gold supported cryptomelane-type manganese dioxide OMS-2 monolithic catalysts and tested their performance for CO oxidation [26]. Yan et al. have described the fabrication of nanowire arrays on glass in which a gold core nanowire is encapsulated within a hemicylindrical shell of manganese dioxide and showed their potential for high capacity, high rate, and high cyclability hybrid electrical energy storage [27]. These studies have shown that the supported gold catalysts exhibit complex behavior, which is dependent upon many variables involved in their preparation, pre-treatment, and catalytic history. In this article, we have reported the synthesis of dispersive and hydrophilic bifunctional Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites stabilized by poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) of two different morphologies by hydrothermal reaction and their catalytic activity on the electrochemical reduction of molecular oxygen. The unique morphologies are formed, simply, by tuning the solvent composition of the hydrothermal reaction that controls the epitaxial growth of manganese oxide on the preformed gold particles. The composites have been characterized by UV–vis, TEM, HRTEM, EDX, FTIR, XRD and XPS spectroscopy. Due to interfacial contact between Au and Mn3O4 particles, the nanocomposites show superior catalytic activity compared to that of their individual counterparts. The changes in the magnetic properties due to the addition of Au to the Mn3O4 particles have also been investigated. 2 Experimental 2.1 Reagents and instruments All the reagents used were of analytical reagent grade. Manganese(II) acetate tetrahydrate (Mn(ac)2·4H2O), tetrachloroauric acid tetrahydrate (HAuCl4·4H2O), poly(N-vinyl-2-pyrrolidone) (PVP K30) and hydrazine monohydrate was purchased from Wako Pure Chemicals, Japan and were used as received. Millipore water was used throughout the course of the investigation. UV–vis spectra were recorded using a Shimadzu 2500 PC spectrophotometer with a 10mm quartz cell. A TECNAI-12 transmission electron microscope (Philips) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) facility operated with an accelerator voltage 100kV was employed to elucidate the morphology and composition of the particles. Samples were deposited on carbon coated copper grid and dried overnight in a vacuum evaporator. High-resolution transmission electron micrographs, dark field scanning tunneling electron micrographs (DF-STEM) and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) pattern were obtained using a JEM-2010 (at Ube Scientific Analysis Laboratory Ltd.), operating at 200kV. Powder X-ray diffraction was performed on an M18XHF-SRA X-ray diffractometer with CuKα radiation (λ ∼1.54056Å) operating at 40kV and 100mA. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic measurements were performed with a PHI-Quantum-2000 X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with AlKα radiation. Infrared spectra were recorded on a JIR-WINSPEC 50 Fourier transform infrared spectrophotometer. Magnetic measurements were performed with quantum design MPMS SQUID magnetometer in a magnetic field varying from +6000 to −6000Oe at 1.85 and 300K. Catalytic reactions were performed by the deposition of metal colloids on glassy carbon (GC) electrodes in the form of disk (Ø=3.0mm) sealed in a Teflon jacket having an exposed geometric surface area of 0.07cm2. GC electrodes were mechanically polished first with no. 2000 emery paper, then aqueous slurries of successively finer alumina powder (down to 0.06μm) with the help of polishing microcloth and then, sonicated for 30min in millipore water. A spiral Pt wire and an Ag/AgCl/KCl(sat.) (having an equilibrium potential of +197mV vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)) were the counter and reference electrodes, respectively. A 30μL suspension of all colloids (four successive 7.5μL depositions followed by drying in air) was placed on the GC electrode and the catalytic performance was measured at 25° C. A 0.1M HClO4 solution (saturated with purified oxygen gas for 30min prior to measurements) was used as the supporting electrolyte to avoid the possible chemical dissolution of the nanoparticles pre-deposited onto the GC electrodes. 2.2 Synthesis of nanocomposites The nanocomposites of Au–Mn3O4 were synthesized by low temperature (ca. 80°C) hydrothermal reaction of manganese acetate from an aqueous ethanolic solution in the presence of preformed gold nanoparticles. The gold particles were synthesized in an aqueous solution through the reduction of HAuCl4 by hydrazine using PVP as stabilizer. The morphology of the nanocomposites was varied by tuning the solvent composition of the reaction medium. 2.2.1 Synthesis of gold nanoparticles Gold nanoparticles were obtained by refluxing a mixed solution of the corresponding metallic salt, stabilizer, and the reducing agent. Typically, a 100mL aqueous solution of a mixture of HAuCl4·4H2O (0.5mM) and PVP (20mM) (R =40) was brought to reflux (ca. 100°C) under stirring. After about 10min, an aqueous solution of N2H4·H2O (10mM) was added very quickly and the color of the solution immediately changed from light yellow to dark red indicating the formation of Au colloidal solutions. The stirring was continued for further 30min for the complete formation of the gold particles. 2.2.2 Synthesis of Mn3O4 nanoparticles A 100mL aqueous ethanolic solution containing a mixture of Mn(ac)2·4H2O (20mM) and PVP (0.8M) (R =40) was brought to reflux (ca. 80°C) under stirring. After about 30min, there was development of brownish yellow coloration from the parent colorless solution. However, the refluxing was continued for overall 2h for the development of the particles. 2.2.3 Synthesis of Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites In a typical synthesis, a 90mL aqueous ethanolic solution of a mixture of Mn(ac)2·4H2O (0.5mM) and PVP (20mM) (R =40) was brought to reflux (ca. 80°C) under stirring. After 10min of the refluxing of the solution, 10mL of preformed gold nanoparticles (0.05mM) was added dropwise continuing 10min to the solution under reflux. The refluxing was continued overall for 2h. After addition of the gold colloid, the color of the sol was slowly begun to change and finally, a brownish red color was seen at the end of the reaction. The solvent composition of the aqueous ethanolic solution was H2O:ethanol=3:1 and 1:1 for the synthesis of two sets of nanocomposites and we designate them as many-to-one (MO) and one-to-one (OO) respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the nanocomposites 3.1.1 Absorption spectroscopy The absorption spectral features of Au, Mn3O4 and their composites are shown in Fig. 1 . Gold nanoparticles exhibit an absorption spectrum with maximum at 520nm corresponding to the characteristic surface plasmon resonance of conduction electrons of the particles (trace a). The electronic absorption spectrum of manganese oxide nanoparticles (trace b) shows three well-defined regions: the first portion from 250 to 410nm, the second from 410 to 585nm and the third one finishing at 800nm The first portion is attributed to the allowed O2− →Mn2+ and O2− →Mn3+ charge transfer transitions [28], and the last two can be reasonably related to d–d crystal field transitions, 3Eg(G)← 3T1g, 3A2g(F)← 3T1g, 3A2g(G)← 3T1g, 3T2g(H)← 3T1g, 3T1g(H)← 3T1g and 3Eg(H)← 3T1g, on octahedral Mn3+ species [29]. Traces c and d represent the absorption spectra of the MO and OO nanocomposites, respectively. The salient feature of physical significance is that the portion of the absorption band due to charge transfer transition of manganese oxide vanishes due to interaction with the gold nanoparticles. This vanishing of charge transfer band is, presumably, due to the chemical bonding or electron transfer to the gold nanoparticles, as a result of strong metal-support interaction [30]. The color change of Mn3O4 nanoparticles is clearly seen before and after Au conjugation. The original color of Mn3O4 particles is yellowish brown, and that of Au is red, while the resulting bifunctional Au–Mn3O4 nanoparticles turned to reddish brown. This suggests that the resulting Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites have inherited the colorimetric character of gold nanoparticles. Inset shows a closer view of the surface plasmon band position of gold nanoparticles in the range of 400–700nm represented by a′, b′, c′ and d′ correspondingly. The broadening of the surface plasmon maxima also indicates strong interaction between Au and Mn3O4 in Au–n3O4 nanocomposites. A wider broadening in case of MO clusters can be attributed to the interaction of many small Au particles at the nanoscale interparticle distances within a single Mn3O4 cluster [31]. Thus, both the vanishing of the charge transfer band and broadening of surface plasmon maximum indicates strong interaction between Au and Mn3O4 clusters in the nanocomposites. 3.1.2 Transmission electron microscopy The morphology of the individual components and their nanocomposites has been characterized by transmission electron microscopy. Fig. 2 shows the TEM images and the corresponding diameter histogram of Mn3O4, Au, many-to-one (MO) and one-to-one (OO) Au–Mn3O4 nanoparticles with particle sizes 25±6nm, 5±1nm, 50±5nm and 20±2nm respectively. In the image of the nanocomposites, the Au particles appear black and Mn3O4 are light colored because Au has a higher electron density and allows fewer electrons to transmit. In Fig. 2(c), many Au particles are attached to one Mn3O4 cluster while in Fig. 2(d) only one Au particle is anchored to a single Mn3O4 cluster substantiating their designation as many-to-one and one-to-one, respectively. 3.1.3 Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy The representative energy dispersive X-ray spectra of PVP-stabilized Mn3O4 and Au–Mn3O4 (MO) particles are shown in Fig. 3 . The EDX pattern of Au–Mn3O4 (MO) nanocomposites (Fig. 3(b)) reveals that the particles are composed of Mn, Au, O, C, N elements. Among those elements, the signals of Mn and Au result from the Mn3O4 and Au particles which form the product. The average atomic ratio of Au:Mn was seen as 1:10.1 and 1:10.2 for MO and OO nanocomposites, respectively as was employed in the starting material (1:10) of the reaction. The signals of C, N, O and Cu elements come from the stabilizer PVP and the supporting TEM grid. 3.1.4 High resolution transmission electron microscopy The high resolution TEM images demonstrate the detailed nanoscopic structures of the Au–Mn3O4 composites. In the high-resolution images (Fig. 4 (a) and (b)), it is seen that Au and Mn3O4 particles are in close contact with each other. The HRTEM image displays the distinct lattice spacing of 0.49nm corresponding to (101) lattice constant of Mn3O4 and that of Au is 0.24nm resulting from a group of (111) planes in fcc structured gold. The HRTEM image demonstrates the single crystalline nature of Mn3O4 which indicates that structural features of Mn3O4 nanoparticles remained after the deposition of Au particles [31]. Fig. 4(c) and (d) are the dark field scanning tunneling electron microscopy (DF-STEM) images of the corresponding nanocomposites at the same positions as those in Fig. 4(a) and (b). The brightness in the image reflects the intensity of scattered electrons from different substances and is proportional to their atomic numbers [32]. In the present systems, the Au particles have the higher atomic number compared to particles and therefore, are imaged as brighter species while the Mn3O4 particles are appeared as lighter one. The selected area electron diffraction pattern (SAED) (Fig. 4(e) and (f)) of the Mn3O4 particles is consistent with tetragonal Mn3O4 with strong ring patterns due to (101), (103) and (220) planes. Insets show the SAED patterns of gold particles in the Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites. The SAED pattern of Mn3O4 further confirms the single crystallinity of the particles [33]. 3.1.5 X-ray diffraction study Powder X-ray diffraction patterns of Au, Mn3O4 and Au–Mn3O4 (MO) are shown in Fig. 5 . The position and relative intensity of all diffraction peaks match with standard fcc structured Au (pattern a) and Mn3O4 (pattern b). On the basis of pattern b, all diffraction peaks can be indexed to the tetragonal hausmannite structure with lattice parameters a = b =5.762Å, and c =9.469Å and space group I4I/amd, which are consistent with the standard values of bulk Mn3O4 (JCPDS# 24-0734) [34]. Additional diffraction peak at ca. 22° may arise due to the presence of trace amount of Mn2O3 in the nanostructures. For further confirmation of the Mn3O4 structures as the predominant phase, the FTIR spectrum and XPS of the Mn3O4 particles are presented in Supporting Information Figs. S1 and S2, respectively. The presence of three bands at 418, 505 and 618cm−1 confirms the presence of Mn3O4 as the major phase [35]. After the deposition of gold nanoparticles on the surface of Mn3O4 particles, the XRD patterns remain unchanged, although weak metallic gold diffraction lines are also evidenced (pattern c). In this pattern, the intensity of Au peaks are weak due to lower wt% than that of individual gold particles while the weak manganese oxide peaks are masked by the relatively stronger gold peaks. The weak and broad reflections at the small angle region (10–30°) is due to the presence of the polymer, PVP attached onto the nanoparticle surface and are found to be in agreement with the earlier reports in literature [36]. After annealing at 500°C in argon atmosphere for 1h, the particles show the same XRD pattern as that before the annealing shown in pattern d, indicating no structural change. This is consistent with the structural stability of the Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites at high temperatures [32]. 3.2 Mechanism of formation of the nanocomposites It is now well-established in the literature that the formation of metal oxides requires a basic medium and usually LiOH/NaOH/KOH are employed for this purpose. However, in the present experiment, the hydrolysis equilibrium with the acetate ions makes the medium basic enough to drive the formation of Mn(OH)2, which is oxidized to Mn3O4 with simultaneous reduction of atmospheric oxygen. The oxygen in the nanoparticle may also originate from the acetate ligand in the [Mn(ac)2] precursor or alternatively, may come from water [37]. After the addition of Au nanoparticles, the Au–Mn3O4 structure is likely derived from the epitaxial growth of Mn3O4 on the gold seeds. The growth of Mn3O4 particles in solution with single or multiple Au nanoparticles is determined by solvent composition that controls the rate of hydrolysis and therefore, the growth of Mn3O4 nanoparticles. Presence of small amount of water may result in slower growth of Mn3O4 particles resulting in smaller nanocrystal accompanied by only one Au particle (OO). The reverse is true for the MO composites. The solvent composition mediates the formation of Au–Mn3O4 particles; higher the percentage of H2O in the solvent mixture, greater the presence of gold nanoparticles in the composites. In addition, in a solution-phase synthesis, impurities or capping agents can change the order of free energies of different facets through their interaction with the crystal surface. This alternation may significantly affect the relative growth rates of different facets. As a result, the facet with a slower growth rate will be exposed more on the nanocrystal surface [38]. Thus, depending on the solvent composition, only one or many gold clusters are attached to the Mn3O4 nanocrystal surface as shown in Scheme 1 . 3.3 Magnetic properties It is known that hausmannite is a black mineral and has a tetragonal crystal structure. In its Mn2+(Mn3+)2O4 structure, the Mn2+ and Mn3+ ions occupy the tetrahedral and octahedral positions of the ‘normal spinel’ structure, respectively. The octahedral symmetry is tetragonally distorted due to the Jahn–Teller effect on Mn3+ ions [32]. Therefore, Mn3O4 has become a model spinel compound for many experimental and theoretical investigations. In order to probe the effect of an applied magnetic field on the dielectric response of Mn3O4 nanoparticles upon addition of Au, the magnetic moment was measured at particular temperatures as a function of applied magnetic field. Fig. 6 displays the magnetic hysteresis loops measured at low temperature (1.85K) of Mn3O4 and Au–Mn3O4 (MO) particles. Like the Mn3O4, the Au–Mn3O4 particles are also superparamagnetic. The saturation moment of the Mn3O4 particles is reaching at ca. 25emu/g while that of Au–Mn3O4 particles is reaching at ca. 8emu/g although 80wt% of Au–Mn3O4 is composed of Mn3O4. The interface communication between nanoscale Au and Mn3O4, thus, leads to the change in magnetization behavior of the Mn3O4 particles. However, inset shows that at high temperature (300K), there is no significant change in the magnetic moment and coercivity of Mn3O4 nanoparticles before and after conjugation of Au particles [39]. This phenomenon may have some relation with the special magnetic properties of Au nanoparticles [40]. 3.4 Catalytic application of Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites toward oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) The large overpotential associated with the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is one of the major challenges which seeks for the development of a high performance cathode catalyst [41]. The ORR is a reaction of indispensable importance in metal air batteries, fuel cells as well as in oxygen sensor [42,43]. Till the past few years, Pt and Pt-based alloys were superior to many other electrocatalysts and are still the most widely used electrocatalysts at low-temperature polymer electrolyte membrane fuel cells (PEMFCs) [44]. However, it has been found that the slow oxygen reduction kinetics on Pt catalysts is among the most limiting factors in the energy conversion efficiency of the state-of-the-art PEMFCs. In addition, due to scarce availability of costly Pt, alternative materials are highly sought for fuel cell applications. Therefore, another viable alternative is the development of new inexpensive non-Pt-based electrocatalysts with a comparable or even better electrocatalytic activity. Gold nanoparticles-based cathodes with controllable size and crystallographic orientation appear as more economically cheap electrocatalysts for the ORR. A combined use of a second catalyst (i.e., manganese oxide nanoparticles) together with gold nanoparticles has recently been suggested as a novel strategy in the fabrication of efficient electrocatalysts toward the ORR. El-Deab and Ohsaka [23] investigated the effect of loading level of binary catalysts comprised of nano-Au and nano-MnO x electrodeposited on glassy carbon electrode on the electrochemical reduction of molecular oxygen in alkaline solution. This is based on the fact that manganese oxide has an excellent catalytic activity toward the chemical disproportination of hydrogen peroxide into water and molecular oxygen [45]. Fig. 7 shows the RRDE voltammograms for the ORR obtained at the (a) pure Mn3O4, (b) pure Au, (c) Au–Mn3O4 (OO) and (d) Au–Mn3O4 (MO) respectively with GC disk electrodes (Ø=3.0mm) in O2-saturated 0.1M HClO4 solution. To make a comparison, 30μL of 0.5mM of each of the colloidal solution was deposited onto the GC electrodes. The concentration of Au nanoparticles was 10-fold lower in the composites than the pure Au used in the experiment. In all sets, the concentration of PVP was small enough (ca. 6.6nM) so as to exclude its effect as insulator for electrical conductivity during the ORR. The HClO4 solution was used as the supporting electrolyte to avoid any possible chemical dissolution of the manganese oxide nanoparticles pre-deposited onto the GC electrode. Significantly enhanced catalytic activity was observed for gold catalysts supported on Mn3O4 nanoparticles, as compared to that of their individual counterparts. In Fig. 7, it is seen that the deposition of Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites (curve c) causes a positive shift of the onset of the ORR and a pronounced improvement in disk current compared to that of the only Au or Mn3O4 particles. However, the higher efficiency of the gold at the composites could be attributed to synergistic effect between Au and Mn3O4 in the composites [46]. The presence of trace amount of Mn2O3 in the composites may also have some influence on the catalytic activity for the oxygen reduction reaction. Moreover, it is seen that the Au–Mn3O4 (MO) are more efficient catalysts than Au–Mn3O4 (OO) composites which is presumably due to the larger interfacial area at the MO composites compared to that of the OO catalysts. The higher the amount of Au deposition on the Mn3O4 cluster, the larger the interfacial area is available at the gold-support interface for catalytic reaction. An overview of the catalytic activity of Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites with those of previous systems, including, Pt-based catalysts and other Au-based catalysts are presented in Table 1 . The enhanced catalytic activity of the Au–Mn3O4 catalyst was attributed to the beneficial presence of higher amount of oxidizable gold species and surface oxygen vacancies resulting from the strong interaction between Au and the reactive surface of Mn3O4 nanoparticles [49]. An increase in 5d vacancy of Au increases the interaction of O2 and Au, thereby enhancing the catalytic activity of Au in the composites [50]. It is also likely that oxygen can dissociate on the Au surface and spill over from Au to the oxygen vacancies in the oxide, which synergistically promotes the adsorption and dissociation of O2. The Au–Mn3O4 particles after evacuation and exposure to oxygen form radical species on the surface of this catalyst. The ability to form such radical species in the presence of oxygen [46] leads to enhanced performance of the Au–Mn3O4 composites in the oxygen reduction reaction. Therefore, the different surface structural features clearly determine the strength of metal–support interaction and thus the catalytic activity. 4 Conclusion The present report demonstrates a simple wet chemical strategy for the synthesis of dispersive and hydrophilic one-to-one (OO) and many-to-one (MO) Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites with the Au and Mn3O4 being in the nanometer contact. This synthetic strategy paves the way for facile preparation of diverse bifunctional and even multifunctional nanomaterials in aqueous solution. It has been found that the solvent composition of the reaction medium strongly affects the morphologies of the products. These two types of Au–Mn3O4 structures offer the particles with distinct surface characteristics and functionalities. Upon inclusion of Au in Mn3O4 clusters, it is seen that the catalytic activity toward the oxygen reduction reaction is significantly enhanced compared to only Au or Mn3O4 particles. The highly superior catalytic performance of gold supported on Mn3O4 nanoparticles is attributed to the cumulative effects resulting from beneficial interaction between the electronically modified Au nanoparticles and the well-defined reactive surface of Mn3O4 particles. The SQUID results show that addition of Au does induce some changes in the magnetic properties of Mn3O4 nanoparticles at low temperature, but not at room temperature. Therefore, nanoparticles combining gold and manganese oxides inherit from the two components special surface characteristics which would greatly enhance the potential application of such composite bifunctional nanomaterials. coredata.dc:description: Gold/manganese oxide nanocomposites have been synthesized by seed-mediated epitaxial growth of manganese oxide on the surface of gold nanoparticles under hydrothermal condition. The architectures of the nanocomposites were varied by tuning the composition of the solvent employed in the reaction medium. The particles have been characterized by UV–vis spectroscopy, transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis, Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopic (XPS) techniques. Magnetic measurements show that there are no significant changes in the magnetic moment and coercivity of Mn3O4 nanoparticles upon conjugation with the gold nanoparticles. These bifunctional nanoconjugates have been found to serve as efficient electrocatalysts in comparison with their individual counterparts for the oxygen reduction reaction. The differences in the structure–function relationship of the Au–Mn3O4 composites arise from distinct surface properties of the catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Solvent-mediated synthesis, characterization and electrocatalytic activity of hydrophilic and dispersive Au–Mn3O4 nanocomposites
